file_metadata.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]
file_metadata.title: "Bioelectricity in Development, Regeneration, and Cancers"

chunks.text: Cell Bio conferences, organized by ASCB and EMBO, showcase researchers in cell biology and emerging interdisciplinary topics, including bioelectricity. This report overviews the Cell Bio 2023 subgroup meeting “Bioelectricity in Development, Regeneration, and Cancers,” which featured 12 talks exploring bioelectricity's role in model systems from cells in culture to mammalian systems. The meeting concluded with a discussion on the field's challenges and opportunities.
chunks.chunk_summary: The Cell Bio 2023 meeting highlighted the role of bioelectricity in development, regeneration, and cancers across various model systems.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Laura Borodinsky presented research on neural cell primary cilia and Sonic Hedgehog (Shh) signal in neural tube development using *Xenopus laevis*.  Dorsoventrally asymmetric Ca²⁺ spikes in the neural tube operate independently in the cytosol versus primary cilia. Noncanonical Shh signal, acting through the TRPC3 channel, regulates ciliary Ca²⁺, influencing SOX2 and neuronal markers, leading to neuronal differentiation. This study highlights the integration of bioelectric signals with morphogen signals and gene regulation during development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Calcium spikes in the neural tube, regulated by noncanonical Shh signaling, influence neuronal differentiation, demonstrating the interplay between bioelectric and morphogen signals.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Emily Bates discussed depolarization's role in regulating Ca²⁺-dependent BMP release in mouse palate development. Anderson–Tawil syndrome, causing neurological and craniofacial defects, is linked to KCNJ2 channel dysfunction. Mouse KCNJ2 knockout in neural crest cells leads to similar craniofacial defects and disrupted BMP signaling. KCNJ2-mediated Vmem depolarization triggers Ca²⁺ transients crucial for BMP release, which is absent in knockout mice, potentially explaining the craniofacial defects.
chunks.chunk_summary: KCNJ2-mediated membrane depolarization and Ca²⁺ transients are essential for BMP release during palate development, and their disruption leads to craniofacial defects.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Mikaela Follmer explored the interplay between Ca²⁺ signaling and SNARE proteins in *Drosophila* wing development. Ca²⁺ oscillations, controlled by Stim and SERCA, along with SNARE complex proteins, are crucial for BMP/Dpp release from wing discs, impacting wing patterning.  SNARE proteins can have opposing effects, enabling tight regulation of BMP/Dpp release. This suggests that Vmem and Ca²⁺-mediated morphogen release regulation might be a conserved mechanism across tissues, working with various morphogens in development.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ca²⁺ oscillations and SNARE proteins regulate BMP/Dpp release in *Drosophila* wing development, suggesting a conserved mechanism for morphogen release control.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: GuangJun Zhang presented research on bioelectric regulation in zebrafish fin patterning. Using the ASAP1 voltage reporter, Vmem dynamics were observed during cleavage, gastrulation, and segmentation. Zebrafish mutants with elongated fins showed transient and ectopic expression of kcnj13/Kir7.1 and kcnj10a. Ectopic expression of other K⁺ channels induced different fin morphologies, suggesting bioelectricity, rather than specific channels, determines fin size and pattern.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem dynamics, observed using ASAP1, play a role in zebrafish fin patterning, with ectopic K⁺ channel expression affecting fin morphology.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Samantha Hack discussed the relationship between bioelectric signals and ROS during *Planaria* regeneration.  Injury-mediated Vmem depolarization triggers Ca²⁺ signaling, crucial for ROS generation, which in turn activates wound repair gene transcription. This highlights a potential link between bioelectricity and metabolism, as ROS are key metabolic components.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem depolarization triggers Ca²⁺ signaling and ROS generation, essential for wound repair in *Planaria*, linking bioelectricity and metabolism.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Daniel Cohen presented on bioelectric reprogramming of collective cell behaviors, developing tools (SCHEEPDOG) for interactive tissue control.  Electric fields controlled skin cell movement, overriding natural safeguards like contact inhibition. In 3D spherical cultures, electrotaxis controlled lumen pressure via ion movement and osmotic changes, potentially applicable to organs with cavities. Electrotaxis-mediated symmetry breaking was observed in 3D cultures. These tools are valuable for investigating bioelectricity's role in various biological processes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Tools like SCHEEPDOG enable control of cell movement and tissue properties using electric fields, offering new avenues for studying bioelectricity's role in various processes.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Chrystian Junqueira Alves discussed mechano-electrical regulation of glioblastoma stem cell migration. Confined migration enhances invasiveness, with endocytosis crucial for this process. Plexins are essential for endocytosis, and Plexin-B2 knockout reduces membrane tension, decreases anionic phospholipid endocytosis, and hyperpolarizes cells, disrupting Ca²⁺ flow needed for confined migration. This connects biochemical, bioelectric, and mechanical signals in cell behavior.
chunks.topic: Mechano-electrical Regulation of Cancer Cell Migration
chunks.chunk_summary: Confined migration enhances glioblastoma invasiveness, with Plexins playing a key role in endocytosis and membrane potential regulation, linking mechanical, bioelectric, and biochemical signals.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Zhuoxu Ge presented on Vmem and cytoskeleton interplay in cell migration. Using CyoFP1-JEDI, Vmem's role in cell cycle progression, proliferation, and migration was observed. NHE is important for migration, depolarizing leading protrusions. This connects the cytoskeleton, ion channels, and Vmem. Dynamic Vmem changes during cell division and shape changes were also observed.
chunks.topic: Vmem and Cytoskeleton in Cell Migration
chunks.chunk_summary: NHE-mediated depolarization of leading protrusions, linking the cytoskeleton, ion channels, and Vmem, is essential for cell migration.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Nathan Belliveau discussed identifying genes supporting neutrophil galvanotaxis. A genome-wide CRISPRi screen in HL60 cells identified TMEM154 (Galvanin), a plasma membrane protein, as crucial for galvanotaxis. Galvanin localizes to the anodic side of cells and inhibits actin polymerization, potentially acting as an electric sensor in mammalian cells.
chunks.chunk_summary: A CRISPRi screen identified TMEM154 (Galvanin) as a key player in neutrophil galvanotaxis, potentially acting as an electric sensor.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Mugdha Sathe presented on zebrafish T cell migration away from wounds due to endogenous electric fields. Neutrophils migrate toward the cathode, while T cells migrate toward the anode. Endogenous electric and osmotic cues are essential for curating the cell population at the wound site for healing.
chunks.chunk_summary: Endogenous electric fields direct T cell migration away from wounds in zebrafish, while neutrophils migrate towards the cathode, highlighting the role of bioelectricity in wound healing.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Ca²⁺ signaling was a recurring theme, involved in cell division, differentiation, migration, and morphogen secretion. Ca²⁺ acts as a central node in a bowtie network, receiving multiple inputs and producing multiple outputs. Understanding how Ca²⁺ relays specific inputs to specific outputs remains a key challenge, potentially requiring investigation of spatiotemporal dynamics and frequency modulation.
chunks.topic: Calcium Signaling as a Central Hub
chunks.chunk_summary: Ca²⁺ signaling, acting as a central hub in various biological processes, requires further investigation to understand its specific input-output relationships.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Cuming Duan discussed TRPV6 regulation of epithelial cell renewal. TRPV6/Ca²⁺-mediated reactivation of skin ionocytes requires sustained mitochondrial Vmem and metabolism. Increased mitochondrial metabolism leads to ROS-induced SGK1 and ATP production, driving ionocyte plasticity. This links mitochondrial bioelectric signaling to cell plasticity and metabolism.
chunks.chunk_summary: TRPV6/Ca²⁺-mediated ionocyte reactivation depends on mitochondrial Vmem and metabolism, linking mitochondrial bioelectricity to cell plasticity.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: Qian Chen presented on Ca²⁺ transients during cell division in fission yeast. Pkd2, a mechanosensitive channel localized to the cleavage furrow, regulates Ca²⁺ spikes during cytokinesis. Pkd2, activated by membrane tension, promotes Ca²⁺ transients. This mechanism is conserved in vertebrate embryos and may be relevant to polycystic kidney disease.
chunks.chunk_summary: The mechanosensitive Pkd2 channel regulates Ca²⁺ transients during cell division, a conserved mechanism from yeast to vertebrates.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: The end-of-session discussion acknowledged the bioelectricity field's progress but noted its lag in broad awareness. Bioelectricity, a holistic property of living systems, requires multidisciplinary expertise.  Addressing the misperception of bioelectricity as epiphenomenal, through science outreach and curriculum integration, is crucial.  The biomechanics field's journey to mainstream acceptance serves as a model.
chunks.topic: Challenges and Opportunities in Bioelectricity Research
chunks.chunk_summary: The bioelectricity field has progressed but needs broader awareness and to overcome the misperception of being epiphenomenal, requiring outreach and curriculum integration.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: The discussion highlighted the fractionation within the bioelectricity field, with isolated research efforts in materials science, ion channel research, and organismal bioelectricity. Integrating these fractions through conferences and collaborative efforts is essential.  Promoting bioelectricity in mainstream science through representation at general conferences is also needed.
chunks.chunk_summary: Integrating the fragmented bioelectricity research areas through conferences and collaborations, and promoting the field in mainstream science, are crucial for its advancement.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: A need for sharing customized tools and techniques within the bioelectricity research community was identified. Developing tutorials and a repository of tools and know-how would lower barriers to entry for young researchers and facilitate collaboration. Virtual gatherings and retreats could further promote knowledge sharing and progress in the field.
chunks.chunk_summary: Sharing customized tools and techniques through tutorials and a central repository, along with virtual gatherings, can enhance collaboration and lower barriers to entry in bioelectricity research.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]

chunks.text: The meeting showcased the excitement and opportunity in the bioelectricity field, with growing participation from early-career scientists. Future meetings should address topics like biosensors and voltage manipulation tools. Continued momentum and integration into mainstream science are envisioned.
chunks.chunk_summary: The bioelectricity field shows promise, with growing interest and the need for future meetings to address emerging topics and further integrate into mainstream science.
chunks.authors: ["Vaibhav P. Pai, PhD", "Guangjun Zhang, PhD", "Michael Levin, PhD"]
